images.title: Evelyn Simak / Dunes and a deep blue North Sea
images.caption: Dunes and a deep blue North Sea. The coastline at Winterton is historically known to be one of the most hazardous parts of the British coastline. On visiting Winterton-on-Sea in 1722, Daniel Defoe commented that all the houses of the village were constructed from the timbers of wrecked ships. In order to stabilise the coastline against erosion marram grass was planted and by the early 19th century dunes had built up, forming a barrier between the high water mark and the ridge on which the lighthouse stands. During the second half of the 20th century the coastline has again changed in that some of the dunes eroded. The area is mostly situated at approximately sea level and erosion and flooding are constant potential risks to the village.

images.title: Reindeer moss in the dunes at Winterton by Evelyn Simak, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Reindeer moss in the dunes at Winterton

images.caption: Hemsby, Norfolk, St Mary the Virgin and war memorial. the church dates to the 12th century.

images.title: Beach Road, Hemsby by Stacey Harris, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Beach Road, Hemsby. Beach Road plays host to a range of eateries and amusements including a fun fair and bingo, crazy golf and several clubs providing family entertainment including dancing and nightly discos.

description: This seaside village is located on the east Norfolk coast just to the south of Winterton on Sea. Local walking highlights include the coastal paths along the beach and the nearby Rollesby Broad and Ormesby Broad. This walk takes you north along the coast past to visit Winterton Nature Reserve. There's a wonderful dune system here with lots of wildlife including the rare natterjack toad. You could extend the walk to visit the nearby Horsey Windpump and Horsey Mere where there's some lovely waterside trails and an old mill to see. Please scroll down for the full list of walks near and around Hemsby. The detailed maps below also show a range of footpaths, bridleways and cycle paths in the area.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Lacon Arms has a nice large garden area with views of the sea. They can be found at postcode NR29 4JG. The pub is dog friendly.
